elements.content: Three new coordination polymers (CPs) of coordinated isoniazid (INH) to Zn­(II) with succinic acid (H2succ), fumaric acid (H2fum), and terephthalic acid (H2bdc) as organic linker, [Zn­(INH)­(succ)] n (1), [Zn­(INH)­(fum)] n (2), and [Zn­(INH)­(bdc)] n (3), respectively, have been characterized. The structure determination by the single crystal X-ray diffraction technique shows a ZnN2O4 distorted octahedral geometry, and the 1D chain is constituted via the INH and carboxylate coordination along with the hydrogen bonding (N–H···O) which comprises a 2D structure. The CPs, 1 and 2, are isostructural and fabricate supramolecular networks by inclined intercatenation of two 2D layers, while 3 shows parallel intercatenation. The electrical conductivity and Schottky barrier diode behavior have been established by the charge transport mechanism of the compounds at the quasi-Fermi level state. The analysis indicates that the compound 1 has the highest mobility (2.53 × 10 –10 m2 V–1 s–1) than 2 (1.86 × 10–10 m2 V–1 s–1) and 3 (1.89 × 10–10 m2 V–1 s–1) and the highest electrical conductivity (2.26 × 10–4 S m–1) than the others (1.12 × 10–4 S m–1 (2) and 1.25 × 10–4 S m–1 (3)). DFT computation of the structural motif of CPs has calculated the band gap (ΔE: 3.93 eV (1), 4.45 eV (2), 4.26 eV (3)), which supports the progression of conductivity.

The CPs, 1 and 2, are isostructural and fabricate supramolecular networks by inclined intercatenation of two 2D layers, while 3 shows parallel intercatenation. The analysis indicates that the compound 1 has the highest mobility (2.53 × 10 -10 m2 V-1 s-1) than 2 (1.86 × 10-10 m2 V-1 s-1) and 3 (1.89 × 10-10 m2 V-1 s-1) and the highest electrical conductivity (2.26 × 10-4 S m-1) than the others (1.12 × 10-4 S m-1 (2) and 1.25 × 10-4 S m-1 (3)). DFT computation of the structural motif of CPs has calculated the band gap (ΔE: 3.93 eV (1), 4.45 eV (2), 4.26 eV (3)), which supports the progression of conductivity.

The CPs, 1 and 2, are isostructural and fabricate supramolecular networks by inclined intercatenation of two 2D layers, while 3 shows parallel intercatenation. elements.content: An extensive research in the field of coordination polymers (CPs) has attracted in the different branches of metal–organic frameworks (MOFs), coordination networks (1D, 2D, 3D), etc. The field explores wide applications in gas storage, separation,catalysis, ion exchange, drug delivery, and sensing applications. N-donor ligands in the presence of a bridging “linker” are commonly used to fabricate CPs. The properties of CPs have been influenced by the metal ion type, flexibility, and chemical functionality of the ligands. Dicarboxylates have been used as “linkers” in the construction of major classes of CPs of various dimensionalities with different coordination modes and sizes. Alkane/​alkene dicarboxylates are more flexible than aromatic dicarboxylates and have been used to design CPs that are efficiently sensitive to external stimuli.The electronic properties are influenced by the steric and electronic nature of organic linkers. Thus, the bulk electronic properties of the polymers may be harmonized by changing the linkers. For example, the CPs synthesized from d10 metal ions (Zn2+, Cd2+) with the conjugated carboxylate organic linkers are found to exhibit semiconductor properties and may be the active components in the photonic and electronic devices. The band gap in the polymer may be tuned by the size and the conjugation of the organic linker. An increase of the size or the π conjugation of the organic linkers can further narrow down the band gaps. Intercatenated/​polycatenated features are very important in the context of semiconductivity of coordination polymers. The length of the bridging ligands is a useful motif to incorporate catenation characteristics. Most CPs are electrical insulators; however, recently several classes of highly ordered CPs are demonstrated that assist band transport. Flexible ligands usually constitute the architect to support charge mobility. Uses of CPs as semiconductor and as Schottky barrier diodes have recently been focused, because of their chemical stability and the structure–property relationship under the influence of external stimuli such as thermal, electric, magnetic, and optical fields.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

An extensive research in the field of coordination polymers (CPs) has attracted in the different branches of metal-organic frameworks (MOFs), coordination networks (1D, 2D, 3D), etc. The field explores wide applications in gas storage, separation,catalysis, ion exchange, drug delivery, and sensing applications. N-donor ligands in the presence of a bridging "linker" are commonly used to fabricate CPs. The properties of CPs have been influenced by the metal ion type, flexibility, and chemical functionality of the ligands. Dicarboxylates have been used as "linkers" in the construction of major classes of CPs of various dimensionalities with different coordination modes and sizes. Alkane/alkene dicarboxylates are more flexible than aromatic dicarboxylates and have been used to design CPs that are efficiently sensitive to external stimuli.The electronic properties are influenced by the steric and electronic nature of organic linkers. Thus, the bulk electronic properties of the polymers may be harmonized by changing the linkers. For example, the CPs synthesized from d10 metal ions (Zn2+, Cd2+) with the conjugated carboxylate organic linkers are found to exhibit semiconductor properties and may be the active components in the photonic and electronic devices. The band gap in the polymer may be tuned by the size and the conjugation of the organic linker. An increase of the size or the π conjugation of the organic linkers can further narrow down the band gaps. Intercatenated/polycatenated features are very important in the context of semiconductivity of coordination polymers. The length of the bridging ligands is a useful motif to incorporate catenation characteristics. Most CPs are electrical insulators; however, recently several classes of highly ordered CPs are demonstrated that assist band transport. Flexible ligands usually constitute the architect to support charge mobility. Uses of CPs as semiconductor and as Schottky barrier diodes have recently been focused, because of their chemical stability and the structure-property relationship under the influence of external stimuli such as thermal, electric, magnetic, and optical fields.

elements.content: We have recently focused our attention to the different aspects of CPs and exploration of their application potential. In this work, we have used alkane/alkene dicarboxylates as bridging ligands and isoniazid (iso­nicotinyl­hydra­zide, INH), a first line anti-mycobacterial drug, as another linker. Isoniazid and its derivatives have been used as linkers to constitute hybrid materials.Three different dicarboxylates, succinic acid (saturated) (H2succ), fumaric acid (single CC bond) (H2fum), and terephthalic acid (aromatic dicarboxylic acid), have been used to synthesize bridging dicarboxylates of the {Zn­(isonia­zid) or Zn­(INH)} motif (). The CPs reported in this work display a surprising effect on the conductivity at an applied potential across it, and [Zn­(INH)­(succ)] n shows the highest activity in the switching applications. The structures of the compounds are supported by single crystal X-ray diffraction measurement and other spectroscopic data. The electrical conductivity of the clusters has been explained by DFT computation of the coordination geometry of [Zn­(iso­nia­zide)­(dicarbox­ylate)] n .

In this work, we have used alkane/alkene dicarboxylates as bridging ligands and isoniazid (isonicotinylhydrazide, INH), a first line anti-mycobacterial drug, as another linker. Isoniazid and its derivatives have been used as linkers to constitute hybrid materials.Three different dicarboxylates, succinic acid (saturated) (H2succ), fumaric acid (single CC bond) (H2fum), and terephthalic acid (aromatic dicarboxylic acid), have been used to synthesize bridging dicarboxylates of the {Zn(isoniazid) or Zn(INH)} motif (). The CPs reported in this work display a surprising effect on the conductivity at an applied potential across it, and [Zn(INH)(succ)] n  shows the highest activity in the switching applications. The structures of the compounds are supported by single crystal X-ray diffraction measurement and other spectroscopic data. The electrical conductivity of the clusters has been explained by DFT computation of the coordination geometry of [Zn(isoniazide)(dicarboxylate)] n .

elements.content: Isoniazid (INH), succinic acid (H2succ), fumaric acid (H2fum), terephthalic acid (H2bdc), and Zn­(NO3)2·​6H2O were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich Chemical Co. Inc. and were used as received. All other chemicals and solvents were of reagent grade and purchased from Merck and used without further purification. Microanalytical data (C, H, N) were collected on a PerkinElmer 2400 CHNS/O elemental analyzer. Spectroscopic data were obtained using the following instruments: IR spectra (KBr disk, 4000–400 cm–1) from a PerkinElmer RX-1 FTIR spectrophotometer. Thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) were performed under a nitrogen atmosphere with a heating rate of 10 °C/min using a Pyris Diamond TG/DTA instrument in the range of 30–500 °C. X-ray powder diffraction was performed using a Bruker D8 ADVANCE X-ray diffractometer. The field emission scanning electron microscopy (FESEM) images were taken by a FEI make Inspect F-50 scanning electron microscope. The optical characterization of all the synthesized compounds was carried out with the help of a Shimadzu 2401 PC UV–vis spectrophotometer, in the range 200–900 nm. The frequency-dependent capacitance was recorded by the computer controlled Agilent make precision 4294A LCR meter. The electrical characterization was performed with the help of a Keithley 2400 SourceMeter, interfaced with a PC.

Experimental Section

Materials and Physical Methods

Isoniazid (INH), succinic acid (H2succ), fumaric acid (H2fum), terephthalic acid (H2bdc), and Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich Chemical Co. Inc. and were used as received. All other chemicals and solvents were of reagent grade and purchased from Merck and used without further purification. Microanalytical data (C, H, N) were collected on a PerkinElmer 2400 CHNS/O elemental analyzer. Spectroscopic data were obtained using the following instruments: IR spectra (KBr disk, 4000-400 cm-1) from a PerkinElmer RX-1 FTIR spectrophotometer. Thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) were performed under a nitrogen atmosphere with a heating rate of 10 °C/min using a Pyris Diamond TG/DTA instrument in the range of 30-500 °C. X-ray powder diffraction was performed using a Bruker D8 ADVANCE X-ray diffractometer. The field emission scanning electron microscopy (FESEM) images were taken by a FEI make Inspect F-50 scanning electron microscope. The optical characterization of all the synthesized compounds was carried out with the help of a Shimadzu 2401 PC UV-vis spectrophotometer, in the range 200-900 nm. The frequency-dependent capacitance was recorded by the computer controlled Agilent make precision 4294A LCR meter. The electrical characterization was performed with the help of a Keithley 2400 SourceMeter, interfaced with a PC.

elements.content: To an aqueous solution (10 mL) of Zn­(NO3)2·​6H2O (0.297 g, 1 mmol) was added succinic acid (H2succ) (0.118 g, 1 mmol) in ethanol (10 mL) neutralized with Et3N (0.212 g, 2 mmol), and isoniazid (0.137 g, 1 mmol) solution (10 mL ethanol) was injected carefully to make an undisturbed layer. It was then allowed to diffuse for a week. The colorless block-shaped crystals were deposited on the glass wall. The crystals were separated mechanically under a microscope and washed with a methanol and water (1:1) mixture, and dried. The yield of [Zn­(INH)­(succ)] n (1) was 72% (0.026 g). Elemental analysis calculated for (C10H11­N3O5­Zn) n (1): C, 37.72; H, 3.48; N, 13.19, Found: C, 37.58; H, 3.44; N, 13.05. IR (KBr pellet, cm–1): 1670 νas(COO–), 1363 νs(COO–).

elements.content: Crystal data and experimental details for data collection and structure refinement are reported in . The crystal structures of compounds 1–3 were determined by X-ray diffraction methods. Suitable single crystals having appropriate dimensions were used for data collection via a Bruker SMART APEX II diffractometer, having graphite-monochromated Mo–Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). The unit cell parameters and crystal-orientation matrices were determined for the complex by least-squares refinements of all reflections within the hkl range −11 ≤ h ≤ 24, −12 ≤ k ≤ 12, −16 ≤ l ≤ 16 (1); −12 ≤ h ≤ 12, −11 ≤ k ≤ 13, −18 ≤ l ≤ 18 (2); −25 ≤ h ≤ 27, −12 ≤ k ≤ 12, −25 ≤ l ≤ 16 (3). The intensity data were corrected for Lorentz and polarization effects. Data were collected applying the condition I > 2σ­(I). The collected data were integrated using the SAINT program, and the absorption corrections were made with SADABS. Full matrix least-squares refinements on F 2 were carried out using SHELXL-97 with anisotropic displacement parameters for all non-hydrogen atoms. Hydrogen atoms were constrained to ride on the respective carbon or nitrogen atoms with isotropic displacement parameters equal to 1.2 times the equivalent isotropic displacement of their parent atom in all cases. All calculations were carried out using SHELXL 97, SHELXS 97, PLATON 99, and ORTEP-3 programs.

X-ray Crystallography

Crystal data and experimental details for data collection and structure refinement are reported in . The crystal structures of compounds 1-3 were determined by X-ray diffraction methods. Suitable single crystals having appropriate dimensions were used for data collection via a Bruker SMART APEX II diffractometer, having graphite-monochromated Mo-Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). The unit cell parameters and crystal-orientation matrices were determined for the complex by least-squares refinements of all reflections within the hkl range -11 ≤ h ≤ 24, -12 ≤ k ≤ 12, -16 ≤ l ≤ 16 (1); -12 ≤ h ≤ 12, -11 ≤ k ≤ 13, -18 ≤ l ≤ 18 (2); -25 ≤ h ≤ 27, -12 ≤ k ≤ 12, -25 ≤ l ≤ 16 (3). The intensity data were corrected for Lorentz and polarization effects. Data were collected applying the condition I > 2σ(I). The collected data were integrated using the SAINT program, and the absorption corrections were made with SADABS. Full matrix least-squares refinements on F 2 were carried out using SHELXL-97 with anisotropic displacement parameters for all non-hydrogen atoms. Hydrogen atoms were constrained to ride on the respective carbon or nitrogen atoms with isotropic displacement parameters equal to 1.2 times the equivalent isotropic displacement of their parent atom in all cases. All calculations were carried out using SHELXL 97, SHELXS 97, PLATON 99, and ORTEP-3 programs.

The Gaussian 09 program package was used to generate optimized geometries and a molecular function of the CPs. The hybrid DFT-B3LYP functional was used throughout the calculations. For C, H, and N, the 6-31G (d) basis set was assigned. The LanL2DZ basis set along with the corresponding pseudo-potential without any symmetry constrain for Zn was used. The vibrational frequency calculation was also executed for these three compounds to ensure that the optimized geometries represent the local minima and there were only positive eigenvalues. The single crystal X-ray coordinates had been used in the calculations. To consign the low lying electronic transitions in the experimental spectra, TDDFT calculations of the complexes were done. We computed the lowest 25 singlet–singlet transition in methanol using the conductor-like polarizable continuum model, and results of the TD-DFT calculations were qualitatively very similar. GaussSum was used to calculate the fractional contributions of various groups to each molecular orbital.
elements.clean_text:
Theoretical Calculation

The Gaussian 09 program package was used to generate optimized geometries and a molecular function of the CPs. The hybrid DFT-B3LYP functional was used throughout the calculations. For C, H, and N, the 6-31G (d) basis set was assigned. The LanL2DZ basis set along with the corresponding pseudo-potential without any symmetry constrain for Zn was used. The vibrational frequency calculation was also executed for these three compounds to ensure that the optimized geometries represent the local minima and there were only positive eigenvalues. The single crystal X-ray coordinates had been used in the calculations. To consign the low lying electronic transitions in the experimental spectra, TDDFT calculations of the complexes were done. We computed the lowest 25 singlet-singlet transition in methanol using the conductor-like polarizable continuum model, and results of the TD-DFT calculations were qualitatively very similar. GaussSum was used to calculate the fractional contributions of various groups to each molecular orbital.

elements.content: Dicarboxylates serve as bridging groups to construct coordination polymers. Upon addition of isoniazid (INH) to an aqueous solution of Zn­(NO3)2 and succinic acid (H2succ)/fumaric acid (H2fum)/​tereph­thalic acids (H2bdc), the complexes­[Zn­(INH)­(succ)] n (1), [Zn­(INH)­(fum)] n (2), and [Zn­(INH)­(bdc)] n (3) are isolated. Infrared spectra of free isoniazid (Supporting Information, Figure S1) show ν­(CO) at 1662 cm–1, and in the free carboxylic acids (Supporting Information, Figures S2–S4), ν­(COO) appear at 1697, 1676, and 1690 cm–1, which shows shifting to lower frequency (Supporting Information, Figure S5) in the complexes and supports the coordination to Zn­(II) and the difference in COO frequencies (Δν = νas – νs) larger than 200 cm–1 maintains the polymerization. The TGA of the compounds determines the thermal stability order 3 (350 °C) > 2 (270 °C) > 1 (240 °C) (Supporting Information, Figure S6). Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns of as-synthesized 1, 2, and 3 exactly match with those simulated from single crystal data, indicating phase purity of the bulk (Supporting Information, Figures S7–S9). The morphological study by FESEM of the compounds is shown in and has revealed that the particle size of 1 is smaller than that of 3, and in the case of 2, it is the largest in the series. This size-dependent morphology of the material may influence some physical characteristics of the compounds.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Synthesis and Formulation

Dicarboxylates serve as bridging groups to construct coordination polymers. Upon addition of isoniazid (INH) to an aqueous solution of Zn(NO3)2 and succinic acid (H2succ)/fumaric acid (H2fum)/terephthalic acids (H2bdc), the complexes[Zn(INH)(succ)] n  (1), [Zn(INH)(fum)] n  (2), and [Zn(INH)(bdc)] n  (3) are isolated. Infrared spectra of free isoniazid (Supporting Information, Figure S1) show ν(CO) at 1662 cm-1, and in the free carboxylic acids (Supporting Information, Figures S2-S4), ν(COO) appear at 1697, 1676, and 1690 cm-1, which shows shifting to lower frequency (Supporting Information, Figure S5) in the complexes and supports the coordination to Zn(II) and the difference in COO frequencies (Δν = νas - νs) larger than 200 cm-1 maintains the polymerization. The TGA of the compounds determines the thermal stability order 3 (350 °C) > 2 (270 °C) > 1 (240 °C) (Supporting Information, Figure S6). Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns of as-synthesized 1, 2, and 3 exactly match with those simulated from single crystal data, indicating phase purity of the bulk (Supporting Information, Figures S7-S9). The morphological study by FESEM of the compounds is shown in  and has revealed that the particle size of 1 is smaller than that of 3, and in the case of 2, it is the largest in the series. This size-dependent morphology of the material may influence some physical characteristics of the compounds.

elements.content: The octahedral units of CPs are shown in . The crystal structures of 1 ((i, ii)) and 2 ((iii, iv)) are isotypical. The compound 1 crystallizes in the monoclinic space group P21/n with Z = 4. Its asymmetric unit contains a distorted octahedral Zn­(II) center, bonded to one INH ligand and one succinate linker, and each Zn­(II) ion shows distorted octahedral geometry coordinated to two INH-N centers, one O donor from INH amide, and three O atoms from two different succinate ligands. Thus, ZnN2O4 coordination arrangement () is achieved. The compound 2 crystallizes in the triclinic space group P1̅ with Z = 4 with coordination arrangement as in 1, ZnN2O4 (). The connectivity of INH and succinate ligands in 1 and the fumarate linker in 2 constitute the two-dimensional (2D) sheet structure with (4,4)-grids as shown in (ii, iv). The lengths of the rectangles are 9.146 × 8.821 Å2 in 1 and 9.444 × 9.202 Å2 in 2 (Supporting Information, Figures S10, S11). The cavity space is crowded and blocked by intercatenation of the linker motif to generate an overall entanglement which is shown in (i, iii). The catenation, considered as a disadvantage for construction of highly porous frameworks, is currently becoming very important because of enhancement of framework stability and generation of stimuli responsive properties. The Zn–N bond lengths are in the range of 2.0990(18)–2.195(2) Å in 1 and 2.1042(16)–2.1969(19) Å in 2, and Zn–O bond lengths are in the range of 1.9973(17)–2.3828(17) Å in 1 and 1.9989 (17)–2.3855(16) Å in 2.
elements.clean_text:
Structural Descriptions of [Zn(INH)(dicarboxylates)] n  (Dicarboxylates: succ (1), fum (2), bdc (3))

The octahedral units of CPs are shown in . The crystal structures of 1 ((i, ii)) and 2 ((iii, iv)) are isotypical. The compound 1 crystallizes in the monoclinic space group P21/n with Z = 4. Its asymmetric unit contains a distorted octahedral Zn(II) center, bonded to one INH ligand and one succinate linker, and each Zn(II) ion shows distorted octahedral geometry coordinated to two INH-N centers, one O donor from INH amide, and three O atoms from two different succinate ligands. Thus, ZnN2O4 coordination arrangement () is achieved. The compound 2 crystallizes in the triclinic space group P1̅ with Z = 4 with coordination arrangement as in 1, ZnN2O4 (). The connectivity of INH and succinate ligands in 1 and the fumarate linker in 2 constitute the two-dimensional (2D) sheet structure with (4,4)-grids as shown in (ii, iv). The lengths of the rectangles are 9.146 × 8.821 Å2 in 1 and 9.444 × 9.202 Å2 in 2 (Supporting Information, Figures S10, S11). The cavity space is crowded and blocked by intercatenation of the linker motif to generate an overall entanglement which is shown in (i, iii). The catenation, considered as a disadvantage for construction of highly porous frameworks, is currently becoming very important because of enhancement of framework stability and generation of stimuli responsive properties. The Zn-N bond lengths are in the range of 2.0990(18)-2.195(2) Å in 1 and 2.1042(16)-2.1969(19) Å in 2, and Zn-O bond lengths are in the range of 1.9973(17)-2.3828(17) Å in 1 and 1.9989 (17)-2.3855(16) Å in 2.

elements.content: The compound 3 crystallizes in the monoclinic space group C2/c. The asymmetric unit of 3 consists of a distorted octahedral Zn­(II) center in a ZnN2O4coordination sphere ((v, vi)), bridged by both the INH ligand and the bdc linker and constitutes a (4,4)-grid of dimensions 11.098 × 9.116 Å2 ((vi); Supporting Information, Figure S12). A report of a Zn­(II)-coordination polymer of INH with bdc shows no coordination of bdc to Zn­(II), while it shows hydrogen bonded secondary interaction. Therefore, we may applaud that it is the first example of a coordination polymer of Zn­(II) with INH and bdc ligands.

elements.content: The absorption spectra have been recorded for the compound deposited thin films of 1, 2, and 3 by preparing a well-dispersed solution in dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO) (insets, ). The energy absorption is observed in the UV region such as 360 nm (1), 310 nm (2), and 320 nm (3). According to Tauc, the optical band gap of the material can be deduced from the absorption spectra of the material, by using the following equation α h ν = A ( h ν − E g ) n where α is the absorption coefficient, E g is the band gap, h is Planck’s constant, ν is the frequency of light, and the exponent n is the electron transition processes dependent constant. A is a constant which is considered as 1 for the ideal case. Using this equation, the calculated optical band gap is 3.39 eV (1), 4.09 eV (2), and 3.98 eV (3). Herein, the value of the exponent “n” in the above equation was considered as n = 1/2. The plot of (αhν)2 vs hν of the synthesized compounds is demonstrated in .

elements.content: Theoretical calculations have shown that the band gaps of CPs (the energy differences between the highest occupied orbitals (HOMOs) and the lowest unoccupied molecular orbitals (LUMOs)) between 1.0 and 5.5 eV serve as an effective semiconductor and have largely been dependent on the ligand conjugation and the dimensions of the CPs.The optical band gaps of the present synthesized compounds are within the semiconductor limit. Moreover, the presence of strong absorbance in the UV and visible wavelength regions predicts some conducting nature of the synthesized compounds. These results motivated us further to check the electrical conductivity of the synthesized compounds. Hence, we carried out the dielectric study of the compounds 1–3.

elements.content: Impedance spectroscopy has been widely used to study the charge transport behavior of nanocrystalline materials. This analysis provides a correlation between the electrical and structural properties of the material. The transport properties of as-prepared CPs, 1, 2, and 3, have been evaluated by the impedance measurement. The capacitance (C), impedance (Z), and phase angle (θ) of the sample were evaluated as a function of frequency (40 Hz to 11 MHz). For this purpose, the polished pellets of the synthesized compounds were taken. High purity ultrafine silver paste was used as electrode on the opposite surfaces of the pellets.

elements.content: The plane impedance (Z) plots, i.e., the Nyquist plots (Z′–Z″), are shown in and have revealed a prominent arc of semicircles which have been contributed by semiconducting grains in the high-frequency region. These semicircles at the high-frequency region are related to the electrode resistance and also reflect the charge transfer resistance at the electrode/composite interface. From , it is clear that the radius of 1 is less than that of 2 and 3 and indicates that 1 facilitates the interfacial charge transfer.

elements.content: Literature review suggests that the electrical conductivity of the present Zn­(II)-INH intercatenated CPs of dicarboxylates appears in the higher range of conductivity data. All of these parameters pointed out that 1 (2.26 × 10–4 S m–1) is a better contender in the view of electrical conductivity than 2 and 3. Motivated by these results, we designed Schottky devices of all synthesized compounds to check further the applicability in electrical field. Hence, we calculated the Schottky parameters and studied the electrical behavior.

elements.content: The Schottky devices of 1, 2, and 3 were fabricated in a sandwich-like ITO/1 and/or 2 and/or 3/Al configuration. Indium tin oxide (ITO) coated glass substrates was cleaned with soap solution, acetone, ethanol, and distilled water sequentially in an ultrasonic bath. The material was dispersed in DMSO medium and ultrasonicated well to form a stable dispersion. A thin film of the material was then prepared on the ITO coated glass by the spin-coating technique at 1200 rpm for 2 min and subsequently dried. Aluminum was chosen as the rectifier metal contact and deposited on the films by a thermal evaporation technique to construct the metal–semiconductor junction. The effective diode area was maintained at 7.065 × 10–6 m2 by a shadow mask.
elements.clean_text:
Fabrication of Schottky Device

The Schottky devices of 1, 2, and 3 were fabricated in a sandwich-like ITO/1 and/or 2 and/or 3/Al configuration. Indium tin oxide (ITO) coated glass substrates was cleaned with soap solution, acetone, ethanol, and distilled water sequentially in an ultrasonic bath. The material was dispersed in DMSO medium and ultrasonicated well to form a stable dispersion. A thin film of the material was then prepared on the ITO coated glass by the spin-coating technique at 1200 rpm for 2 min and subsequently dried. Aluminum was chosen as the rectifier metal contact and deposited on the films by a thermal evaporation technique to construct the metal-semiconductor junction. The effective diode area was maintained at 7.065 × 10-6 m2 by a shadow mask.

elements.content: The presence of strong absorbance in the UV and visible wavelength regions of the synthesized compounds prophesies some impact of charge transport phenomena. Furthermore, the decreased value of the optical band gap for 1 than the other two compounds interpreted some better possibility of formation of a metal–semiconductor barrier with [Zn­(INH)­(succ)] n (1). Hence, for a better understanding of the charge transport phenomenon, electrical characterization was accomplished by the thin films devices of the well-dispersed solution of compounds deposited on top of ITO coated glass substrates. To analyze the electrical properties, we have measured the current at the corresponding applied bias voltage sequentially within the limit of ±2 V. represents the current–voltage (I–V) characteristics curves for 1, 2, and 3 based thin film devices under dark condition.

elements.content: Evidently, the current–voltage characteristic curves in show that the devices based on the CPs (1–3) exhibit highly nonlinear rectifying behavior. The nonlinearity of the I–V characteristic indicates that the prevalent conduction mechanism is non-Ohmic in nature. The nature of the I–V curve represents the rectifying in nature, similar to the Schottky diode behavior. The rectification ratio of 1 is 176 under dark condition and those of 2 and 3 are 81.73 and 80.62, respectively.

elements.content: A good understanding of the MS junction requires analysis of the charge transport phenomena of the material. Therefore, for a better insight, we investigated the I–V curves in the light of space charge limited current (SCLC) theory. Using this theorem, the two important parameters of charge transport, effective carrier mobility (μ eff ) and transient response time (τ), were evaluated. Effective carrier mobility was estimated from the higher voltage region of the I vs V 2 graph () by the Mott–Gurney equation: I = 9 μ e f f ε 0 ε r A 8 ( V 2 d 3 ) Here, d is the thickness of the film which was considered to be about ∼1 μm for our device.

elements.content: Transit time (τ) of the charge carriers is one of the key parameters to analyze charge transport across the junction. For this purpose, τ was evaluated from , by using the slope of the forward I–V curve, shown in . τ = 9 ε 0 ε r A 8 d ( V I ) Estimated values of effective carrier mobility and lifetimes are presented in . The results demonstrate that the charge transport properties of the compound 1 are far better than those of the other two. The mobility implies higher transport through the MS junction, and the lifetime reveals the average time of a free charge carrier before being recombined. All of these factors corroborate the eventual superiority of 1 than 2 and 3.

Lattice matching and deformation potentials have been used to generate the Schottky electrical contact; the deformation commonly refers to the band gap which is commonly the energy difference between the highest occupied and lowest unoccupied MOs (ΔE = E LUMO – E HOMO, eV). In CPs, the absolute deformation potentials (ADPs) are used to determine the band gap. The coordinated polymer has an organic and inorganic hybrid nature, so the band gap may be influenced by the electronic feature of both. In CPs of d10 electronic configuration, the band edges are often defined by electronic states on the organic ligand along with geometry strain of the network. DFT optimization of the structure of the coordination motif of CP has been used to calculate ΔE (the difference in energy of HOMO and LUMO) (Supporting Information, Tables S1, S2 (CP-1, 1); Tables S3, S4 (CP-2, 2); Tables S5, S6 (CP-3, 3)) which may match with the band gap obtained from Tauc’s plot (). A small increment in calculated band gap may be assigned to the geometry factor which has not been considered in the use of calculation using a single motif. However, the movement in band gap follows the experimental results ().
elements.clean_text:
DFT Computation and Band Gap

Lattice matching and deformation potentials have been used to generate the Schottky electrical contact; the deformation commonly refers to the band gap which is commonly the energy difference between the highest occupied and lowest unoccupied MOs (ΔE = E LUMO - E HOMO, eV). In CPs, the absolute deformation potentials (ADPs) are used to determine the band gap. The coordinated polymer has an organic and inorganic hybrid nature, so the band gap may be influenced by the electronic feature of both. In CPs of d10 electronic configuration, the band edges are often defined by electronic states on the organic ligand along with geometry strain of the network. DFT optimization of the structure of the coordination motif of CP has been used to calculate ΔE (the difference in energy of HOMO and LUMO) (Supporting Information, Tables S1, S2 (CP-1, 1); Tables S3, S4 (CP-2, 2); Tables S5, S6 (CP-3, 3)) which may match with the band gap obtained from Tauc's plot (). A small increment in calculated band gap may be assigned to the geometry factor which has not been considered in the use of calculation using a single motif. However, the movement in band gap follows the experimental results ().

elements.content: The trends observed in valence and conduction bands in 1, 2, and 3 are attributed to the extended conjugation of the bdc linker (3) to conjugation in 2, followed by no conjugation in 1. This also supports that CP-1, 1 shows the highest activity in the impedance plot (), Bode plot (), and AC conductivity plot ().
elements.clean_text: The trends observed in valence and conduction bands in 1, 2, and 3 are attributed to the extended conjugation of the bdc linker (3) to conjugation in 2, followed by no conjugation in 1. This also supports that CP-1, 1 shows the highest activity in the impedance plot (), Bode plot (), and AC conductivity plot ().

elements.content: Isoniazid bridges Zn­(II) CPs with carboxylato linkers (succinic acid, fumaric acid, terephthalic acid), [Zn­(INH)­(succ)] n (1), [Zn­(INH)­(fum)] n (2), and [Zn­(INH)­(bdc)] n (3), are characterized. The CPs exhibit electrical conductivity and reveal Schottky barrier diode behavior. The analysis reports the best performance of [Zn­(INH)­(succ)] n (1) than the others (2, 3). The conductivity has been rationalized by band gap measurement and has been supported by DFT computation of optimized geometry of the motif. The highest mobility in 1 may be due to the lowest barrier height and series resistance than the others. The subtle structural change from saturated in 1 (succ2–), one CC bond in 2 (fum2–), to extended conjugation in C6H4 (3) (bdc2–) may be the reason for conductivity and charge mobility change in the CPs.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

Isoniazid bridges Zn(II) CPs with carboxylato linkers (succinic acid, fumaric acid, terephthalic acid), [Zn(INH)(succ)] n  (1), [Zn(INH)(fum)] n  (2), and [Zn(INH)(bdc)] n  (3), are characterized. The CPs exhibit electrical conductivity and reveal Schottky barrier diode behavior. The analysis reports the best performance of [Zn(INH)(succ)] n  (1) than the others (2, 3). The conductivity has been rationalized by band gap measurement and has been supported by DFT computation of optimized geometry of the motif. The highest mobility in 1 may be due to the lowest barrier height and series resistance than the others. The subtle structural change from saturated in 1 (succ2-), one CC bond in 2 (fum2-), to extended conjugation in C6H4 (3) (bdc2-) may be the reason for conductivity and charge mobility change in the CPs.

To an aqueous solution (10 mL) of Zn­(NO3)2·​6H2O (0.297 g, 1 mmol) was added succinic acid (H2succ) (0.118 g, 1 mmol) in ethanol (10 mL) neutralized with Et3N (0.212 g, 2 mmol), and isoniazid (0.137 g, 1 mmol) solution (10 mL ethanol) was injected carefully to make an undisturbed layer. It was then allowed to diffuse for a week. The colorless block-shaped crystals were deposited on the glass wall. The crystals were separated mechanically under a microscope and washed with a methanol and water (1:1) mixture, and dried. The yield of [Zn­(INH)­(succ)] n (1) was 72% (0.026 g). Elemental analysis calculated for (C10H11­N3O5­Zn) n (1): C, 37.72; H, 3.48; N, 13.19, Found: C, 37.58; H, 3.44; N, 13.05. IR (KBr pellet, cm–1): 1670 νas(COO–), 1363 νs(COO–).

The other two complexes, [Zn­(INH)­(fuma)] n (2) (79%) and [Zn­(INH)­(bdc)] n (3) (82%), were also isolated following the identical procedure. Microanalytical data for (C10H9­N3O5­Zn) n (2): C, 37.93; H, 2.86; N, 13.27, Found: C, 37.78; H, 2.80; N, 13.18. IR (KBr pellet, cm–1): 1669 νas(COO–), 1347 νs(COO–). (C14H11­N3O5­Zn) n (3): C, 45.89; H, 3.02; N, 11.46, Found: C, 45.94; H, 2.97; N, 11.36. IR (KBr pellet, cm–1): 1671 νas(COO–), 1389 νs(COO–).
